SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.xhive.core.interfaces
Interface XhiveSessionIf

public interface XhiveSessionIf

Represents an extended interaction between an application and the connected database. A session provides the transaction services that enable you to perform persistent operations.

Your application can create multiple sessions, each corresponding to a particular subtask that your application performs. Sessions serve to isolate the operations performed in the different subtasks of an application. If more than one session uses a given persistent object, each session has its own local representation of that object. Each session locks and unlocks the object as necessary. The session ensures that applications perform only valid persistent operations on persistent objects

A session can be obtained by using the XhiveDriverIf interface, which can be acquired by using the XhiveDriverFactory class.

(c) X-Hive Corporation B.V. (www.x-hive.com)

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

Field Detail

WAIT

static final int WAIT
Wait option: Transactions wait indefinitely for locks.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0
See Also:
Constant Field Values

NO_WAIT

static final int NO_WAIT
Wait option: Transactions do not wait for locks.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0
See Also:
Constant Field Values

COMMIT_NOWRITE_NOSYNC

static final int COMMIT_NOWRITE_NOSYNC
Commit option: Do not write log records. The commit is processed internally, but the log records of the transaction are not yet written to the operating system. If the X-Hive/DB server terminates abnormally soon after the commit returns, the updates of the transaction may be lost. Use this option only if this is not a problem for your application.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.1
See Also:
Constant Field Values

COMMIT_WRITE_NOSYNC

static final int COMMIT_WRITE_NOSYNC
Commit option: Write log records, but do not force them to disk. The log records of the transaction are written to the operating system disk cache, but the operating system disk cache is not flushed to the physical disk. If the X-Hive/DB server terminates abnormally, but the system stays up, the updates of the transaction will be preserved. If the system crashes soon after the commit returns, the updates of the transaction may be lost. Use this option only if this is not a problem for your application.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.1
See Also:
Constant Field Values

COMMIT_WRITE_SYNC

static final int COMMIT_WRITE_SYNC
Commit option: Write log records and force them to disk. This is the normal and most reliable way to commit. After the commit returns, the transaction is durable even if the system crashes. This option is used in the versions of commit() and checkpoint(boolean) without the commitOption parameter.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.1
See Also:
Constant Field Values
Method Detail

begin

void begin()

Begins a transaction.

The current session must be outside a transaction when you call this method. The thread that calls this method must be joined to this session.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

checkpoint

void checkpoint()

Commits all persistent operations executed since the last begin() or checkpoint(). All read and write locks remain active.

A transaction must be active, and a user must be connected to a database, when you call this method.

The thread that calls this method must be joined to this transaction.

All persistent operations executed since the most recent begin or checkpoint are reflected in the connected database.

When the method returns, this transaction remains active.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

checkpoint

void checkpoint(boolean downgradeLocks)

Commits all persistent operations executed since the last begin() or checkpoint(), and potentially downgrades all locks acquired during the current transaction.

A transaction must be active when you call this method.

The thread that calls this method must be joined to this transaction.

All persistent operations executed since the most recent begin or checkpoint are reflected in the connected database.

When the method returns, this transaction remains active.

Parameters:
downgradeLocks - when true, all write locks are downgraded to read locks, allowing other transactions to read the data.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

checkpoint

void checkpoint(boolean downgradeLocks,
                int commitOption)
This function is just like checkpoint(boolean), but allows you to use faster and less reliable ways to commit.

Parameters:
commitOption - One of COMMIT_NOWRITE_NOSYNC, COMMIT_WRITE_NOSYNC or COMMIT_WRITE_SYNC
Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.1

commit

void commit()

Commits the current transaction.

A transaction must be active when you call this method. The thread that calls this method must be joined to this transaction.

This method terminates the transaction started by the most recent begin() and releases all locks held by this transaction. All persistent operations executed since the most recent begin() or checkpoint() are reflected in the connected database.

When the method returns, the transaction does not remain active.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

commit

void commit(int commitOption)
This function is just like commit(), but allows you to use faster and less reliable ways to commit.

Parameters:
commitOption - One of COMMIT_NOWRITE_NOSYNC, COMMIT_WRITE_NOSYNC or COMMIT_WRITE_SYNC
Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.1

connect

void connect(java.lang.String userName,
             java.lang.String password,
             java.lang.String databaseName)

Connect to a specific database, providing a username and password.

A user must be connected to a database before transactions can be started.

Parameters:
userName - a username.
password - a password.
databaseName - a database name. When connecting as superuser (e.g., to create a database), this parameter should be null.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

connect

void connect(java.lang.String databaseName,
             javax.security.auth.callback.CallbackHandler callbackHandler)
Connect to a specific database, using the Java Authentication and Authorization Service for authentication, which must have been enabled at the server side.

Parameters:
databaseName - A database name. You cannot connect as superuser with this method.
callbackHandler - A handler to retrieve username, password, etc.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0

disconnect

void disconnect()
Disconnect the current user from the current database. After calling this method no transactions can be started anymore with this session, until a new connect is done.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

getDatabase

XhiveDatabaseIf getDatabase()
Get the interface of the database being handled by this transaction.

Returns:
The database interface, or null when connected as superuser.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

int getCacheMaximumPages()
Gets the maximum number of buffer pages that can be allocated in this server's cache.

Returns:
The maximum number of buffer pages that can be allocated in this server's cache
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

getFederation

XhiveFederationIf getFederation()
Get the federation object. The federation object can be used to create and delete databases.

Returns:
The federation object for this session.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

getUser

XhiveUserIf getUser()
Get the user object of the user connected by this connection. This method can only be used if a transaction is active.

Returns:
The user connected by this session. If the user is connected as superuser then null is returned.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

getWaitOption

int getWaitOption()
Gets the lock-waiting option for this session.

Returns:
The lock-waiting option for this session; one of the following constants defined in the XhiveSessionIf interface:
NO_WAIT
The session does not wait for locks.
WAIT
The session waits indefinitely for locks.
n
The session waits for n milliseconds.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0
See Also:
setWaitOption(int)

isConnected

boolean isConnected()
Get the current session connection status

Returns:
true if a user is connected to the session.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

isOpen

boolean isOpen()
Get the current transaction status.

Returns:
true when the transaction is active (a begin() has been called, and no commit() or rollback() has been called yet).
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

isJoined

boolean isJoined()
Tests whether the currently active Java thread is joined with this session.

Returns:
True if the currently active thread is joined with this session; otherwise, false
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0
See Also:
join()

getJoinedThread

java.lang.Thread getJoinedThread()
Gets the thread that is currently joined to this session.

Returns:
The thread that is currently joined to this session (or null if none).
Since:
X-Hive/DB 7.0

join

void join()

Joins the currently active Java thread with this session.

A transaction is bound to the current thread of execution. When a session starts in thread A, and thread B wants to use this transaction, then it has to join this session before using it.

There can be only one thread joined to a particular session at a particular time.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

waitedJoin

void waitedJoin()
Wait for the currently joined thread (if any) to leave and then join the session.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0

leave

void leave()
Makes the currently active Java thread leave this session. The thread is no longer joined to this session and another thread can now join this session.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

rollback

void rollback()
Roll back this transaction. All changes made during the transaction (up to the most recent call to begin() or checkpoint() are lost.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

setWaitOption

void setWaitOption(int option)

Specifies whether this session should wait for locks held by other sessions.

If this method is not called, the session will wait for locks indefinitely.

Parameters:
option - The lock-waiting option to be used by this session; one of the following constants defined in the XhiveSessionIf interface:
NO_WAIT
The session does not wait for locks.
WAIT
The session waits indefinitely for locks.
n
The session waits for n milliseconds.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0
See Also:
getWaitOption()

getReadOnlyMode

boolean getReadOnlyMode()
Get the current read-only mode.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 5.0
See Also:
setReadOnlyMode(boolean)

setReadOnlyMode

void setReadOnlyMode(boolean readonly)

Specifies whether this session is readonly. By default, sessions are read/write. Readonly transactions do not take any locks, this may improve concurrency. Instead of using locks, readonly transactions get a consistent view of the database by using a snapshot view. This is a view of the state of the database at the time that the transaction called begin().

This method throws an exception if this session is currently in a transaction. If this method is called in a replicator, it is ignored. Transactions in a replicator are always readonly.

Parameters:
readonly - Whether this session should be read-only.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 3.0.1

isTerminated

boolean isTerminated()
Tests whether this session has been terminated.

Returns:
true if this session has been terminated, otherwise false.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

terminate

void terminate()
Terminate this transaction.

Terminating a transaction releases all of its resources (memory allocated to the Session object), after calling the terminate() method the Session object cannot be used anymore. This method must only be called when the transaction has been aborted or committed and the resources are no longer needed. When the resources are still needed, for example in a Sessionpool the terminate() method should not be called.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 2.0

setUserClassLoader

void setUserClassLoader(java.lang.ClassLoader classLoader)
Sets the class-loader to use to find user defined classes. These are used in:
  • Context Conditioned Index nodefilters.
  • User defined functions in XPath.
  • User defined functions in XQuery.
Most common usage of this method is in a J2EE environment, where the user classes are in the servlet directory, and the xhive-jars are in a servlet engine directory, loaded by a different class-loader. Then you may want to call 
session.setUserClassLoader(this.getClass().getClassLoader());

When using pools of sessions where sessions may be used in different contexts, you should set the user-class loader every time you use a session.

When set to a non-null value here, it will overrule any classloader set on the driver, you can set the user-classloader on the driver if you know all sessions will work in the same classloading context.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 3.0.2
See Also:
XhiveDriverIf.setUserClassLoader(ClassLoader), XhiveCCIndexIf.indexDocument(Document), XhiveXQueryExtensionFunctionIf, XhiveXPathContextIf.addFunctionBinding(String, String)

createTemporaryDocument

XhiveDocumentIf createTemporaryDocument()
Creates a temporary X-Hive/DB document, without any content. The difference with getDatabase().getRoot().createDocument(null, null, null); is that the document returned does not create a lock on any existing locking context. Also, the document cannot be added to any library.

Use cases for such documents include temporary documents that are used to build up content that need not become persistent (this is also why the document is empty initially).

Returns:
An empty X-Hive/DB Document.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 4.0.1

createTemporaryBlob

XhiveBlobNodeIf createTemporaryBlob()
Creates a temporary blob. The blob cannot be added to a library, nor can it be used after the current transaction has ended.

Returns:
An empty blob.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 7.0

getTemporaryDOMImplementation

DOMImplementation getTemporaryDOMImplementation()
Get a DOMImplementation object that creates temporary X-Hive/DB documents. The object returned also implements DOMImplementationLS.

Returns:
A DOMImplementation object
Since:
X-Hive/DB 7.0

isRollbackOnly

boolean isRollbackOnly()
Returns true if the current transaction is rollback only.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.1

setRollbackOnly

void setRollbackOnly()
Sets the current transaction to rollback only. If you try to checkpoint or commit the transaction later, an exception will be thrown.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.1

interrupt

void interrupt()
Interrupts the session. This method can be called from another thread than the joined thread of this session. At irregular places in the X-Hive/DB code, a check is done whether the session has been interrupted. If so, it will throw XhiveInterruptedException. This can be useful to break off long running actions like complicated queries.

Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.0

getDriver

XhiveDriverIf getDriver()
Returns the driver this session was created on.

Returns:
A driver object, the one used to create this session.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.0

getUpdateTimeStamp

XhiveSessionIf.TimeStamp getUpdateTimeStamp()
Retrieve a timestamp to be used in waitForTimeStamp(com.xhive.core.interfaces.XhiveSessionIf.TimeStamp). Use this on a session of a replication master to wait for updates at a replicator.

Returns:
A timestamp that can only be used to call waitForTimeStamp(com.xhive.core.interfaces.XhiveSessionIf.TimeStamp).
Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.0

waitForTimeStamp

void waitForTimeStamp(XhiveSessionIf.TimeStamp timeStamp)
Wait on a replicator for updates that were done at the master to propagate. Use this method on a session of a replicator. A transaction that calls begin() after having waited for a timestamp will see all changes committed at the master before the timestamp was retrieved.

Parameters:
timeStamp - A timestamp retrieved by calling getUpdateTimeStamp() at the master.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.0

getSessionName

java.lang.String getSessionName()
Retrieve the session name as set by XhiveDriverIf.createSession(String name).

Returns:
The name of the session.
Since:
X-Hive/DB 6.1
